Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 46185-001 
Cluster—Research and Development Technical Assistance (C-RDTA)  
December 2012 
 
 
 
Developing Impact Evaluation Methodologies, 
Approaches, and Capacities in Selected Developing 
Member Countries
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ERD  –  Economics and Research Department 
  IEC  –  Impact Evaluation Committee 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Cluster—Research and development technical assistance  
(C-RDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Public  sector  management  (economic  and  public  affairs 
management) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting economic efficiency and enabling 
business  environment,  widening  access  to  markets  and 
economic  opportunities);  social  development  (human 
development);  private  sector  development  (policy  reforms); 
capacity development (institutional development) 
Location (impact)  –  Rural (high); urban (high) 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  B. N. Lohani, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development 
Chief Economist  C. Rhee, Economics and Research Department (ERD) 
Assistant Chief  C.Y. Park, Economic Analysis and Operations Support Division, ERD 
Economist 
   
Team leader  K. Y. Nam, Senior Economist, ERD 
Team members  R. Bolt, Advisor, Southeast Asia Department 
J. Brommelhorster, Principal Economist, East Asia Department 
H. Carlsson, Lead Development Effectiveness Specialist, South Asia 
Department 
C. Edmonds, Senior Economist, Pacific Department 
P. R. Halili, Economics Officer, ERD 
T. Tamaki, Principal Regional Economist, Central and West Asia 
Department 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) efforts to measure, monitor, and manage for 
development results include conducting impact evaluations. Impact evaluation may be defined 
as  an  assessment  of  changes  in  the  well-being  of  individuals  that  can  be  attributed  to a 
particular project, program, or policy. Thus, the central question of an impact evaluation is what 
would  have  happened  to  those  receiving  the  intervention  had  they  not  received  it. 
Mainstreaming impact evaluation in ADB operations helps improve the quality of development 
policy and design of projects, eventually leading to improved development effectiveness for 
developing member countries (DMCs). It assists ADB and DMCs to allocate limited resources 
more efficiently, guide the design of more effective interventions, and enhance evidence-based 
policy dialogue. The impact evaluation initiative was piloted in ADB through a research and 
development technical assistance (TA) in 2010.1 The concept paper for the proposed cluster 
regional  research  and  development  TA  was  approved  by  the  vice-president  (knowledge 
management and sustainable development) on 28 August 2012. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Bilateral and multilateral development agencies spend more than $30 billion each year 
on  social  development  programs,  with  developing  countries  spending  another  $300  billion 
annually. However, the development effectiveness of this spending is not always clear and 
evidence on its impact is often scant. In particular, it is not known how much of Asia’s recent 
improvement in poverty reduction and human capital outcomes has been due to development 
spending and how much is a trickle-down effect of the region’s rapid economic growth. This lack 
of information limits the ability of policy makers and development partners to further improve 
effectiveness of the development spending through proper design of programs, projects, and 
other interventions. 
 
3.  ADB's economic sector work, cost–benefit analysis, as well as design and monitoring 
frameworks, collect information that provides a basis for identifying project performance both in 
advance (ex ante) and after completion (ex post). The ex ante analysis is useful for designing 
projects  and monitoring  performance.  After  project  completion, the Independent  Evaluation 
Department (IED) validates project performance rating reported in the project completion report 
(PCR). The final ratings assigned form the basis for the success rates. The PCR lessons are 
also reviewed and updated in IED's validation reports. In selected cases, IED also conducts 
project performance evaluation of projects, usually at least after 2 to 3 years with additional 
focus on project impacts and their sustainability. However, the ex-post assessment of the causal 
links between inputs, outputs, outcomes, and impact is often limited by the lack of reliable, 
carefully  constructed  counterfactuals  and  baseline  surveys,  thus,  limiting  accountability  for 
development outcomes. These counterfactuals and baseline surveys are best started early in 
the project cycle as part of project monitoring and evaluation system. An early start allows for 
mainstreaming and systematic assessments of impacts and development effectiveness at mid-
term and project completion. Impact evaluation should also be built into the project design rather 
than conceptualized after approval, wherever feasible. Impact evaluations should ideally be 
done by regional departments to ensure ownership of the process and outcome. 
 
4.  ADB recognized the need to more systematically measure outcomes and impact to 
ensure the development effectiveness of its programs and projects. The TA for Implementing 
                                                
1 ADB. 2010. Implementing Impact Evaluation at ADB. Manila (TA 7680-REG). 
2 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 31 August 2012.

2   
Impact Evaluation at ADB supported the initiation of five impact evaluation studies—in Georgia, 
Mongolia, Nepal, Viet Nam, and the Pacific region (covering Papua New Guinea, Solomon 
Islands, and Timor-Leste)—and impact evaluation training programs and awareness building 
events for staff, providing a key step toward mainstreaming impact evaluation in ADB operations. 
However,  increasing  and  mainstreaming  impact  evaluation  into  ADB  operations  requires 
continuation and expansion of impact evaluation initiatives over an extended period of time. 
Additional resources will be required to (i) initiate an increasing number of comprehensive 
awareness  raising  and  capacity  building  activities  in  DMCs;  (ii)  undertake  methodological 
research to adopt available tools and techniques to sector- and theme-specific needs; and, (iii) 
provide ―seed‖ funds to expand the conduct of impact evaluation studies in ADB operations. The 
proposed TA is expected to address these needs. 
 
5.  Impact evaluations at ADB have so far been largely carried out through the individual 
efforts of regional departments and, recently, through the ADB wide TA for Implementing Impact 
Evaluation at ADB. Under the TA for Implementing Impact Evaluation at ADB, although the 
regional departments are responsible for the final outputs of the impact evaluation studies and 
their quality, the dissemination of the results of the impact evaluations has been limited. The 
reports, data and other information are also stored in the respective regional department, with 
little scope for cross-referencing or exchange of knowledge. Therefore, there is  a need to 
expand the role of the Economics and Research Department (ERD) from coordination to also 
include (i) establishing a repository for impact evaluations, with accessibility for staff of ADB and 
DMCs; (ii) facilitating the exchange of knowledge (experience and lessons) among ADB staff 
and DMCs; and, (iii) providing technical support to regional departments on the design and 
implementation of impact evaluation studies and their preparation and finalization. 
 
6.  An important lesson learned from the TA for Implementing Impact Evaluation at ADB is 
that time frames for impact evaluation studies are typically long, and hence the commitment to 
individual studies needs to match the implementation period of the projects. Moreover, impacts 
of projects can occur during, immediately after, or even long after project implementation. For 
example, some education or health interventions can have measurable impacts during project 
implementation, impacts of transport or energy projects will only occur after completion, while 
projects aimed at improving access to markets or environment may take years to demonstrate 
an impact. Cluster TA modality, given the option that individual studies can be covered through 
multiple subprojects, serves as the appropriate modality as the longer term engagement does 
not require tying down the entire resource requirements at onset of the TA. Cluster modality will 
also allow for TA to be more responsive to the emerging needs and demands of the DMCs, 
while reducing costs otherwise devoted for processing individual studies as standalone TAs. 
 
7.  Another lesson from the TA for Implementing Impact Evaluation at ADB is that the 
design of the baseline study is crucial to the success of evaluation. If the baseline study is 
weakly designed or implemented, it will be very difficult to make the necessary changes later 
and the resulting evaluation will be unreliable. Careful planning and technical support early on in 
the  impact  evaluation  study  is  important  to  ensure  high-quality  outputs.  Front-end  support 
should include systematic training and capacity building for ADB staff and DMC officials who will 
be involved in conducting impact evaluation studies—training that will cover all aspects of 
impact evaluation, including formulating proper research questions, designing study instruments, 
fieldwork, and data analysis. Technical support should also include direct technical advice in the 
appropriate  design  of  impact  evaluation  methodologies  and  survey  instruments,  and  their 
application on the ground. A corollary lesson is that technical advice is best provided with direct 
knowledge of the conditions on the ground. Technical staff and external experts need to visit 
project sites and survey areas in order to give proper technical advice.

3 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The  envisaged  impact  of  the  TA  is  improved  development  effectiveness  of  ADB-
designed projects responsive to the development needs of DMCs. The envisaged outcome of 
the TA is that impact evaluation is mainstreamed3 in ADB operations through each subproject 
resulting in well-designed and -monitored ADB projects in DMCs.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
1.  Technical Assistance Cluster 
 
9.  The  TA  will  comprise  three  subprojects,  with  each  subproject  covering  5  impact 
evaluation studies, for a total of 15 studies distributed over the five ADB regional departments. 
 
2.  Subproject 1 
 
10.  Subproject 1 will comprise two main components: (i) the conduct of 5 impact evaluation 
studies applying various methodologies and survey instruments; and (ii) the development of 
impact evaluation methodologies, approaches, and capacities in both ADB and its DMCs.
 
 
11.  Component 1: Conduct of impact evaluation studies. This component will support 
the conduct of a number of impact evaluation studies while ensuring that at least one study is 
supported in each of the five regions (Central and West Asia, East Asia, the Pacific, South Asia, 
and Southeast Asia). On average, $200,000 will be allocated to each region for conduct of 
impact evaluation studies under the subproject.  Activities under the individual studies may 
include designing the study methodology and survey instruments; conducting baseline, mid-line, 
and end-line surveys; and producing the study reports. The TA will endeavor to support the 
conduct of full impact evaluation studies from beginning to end within the time frame of the TA. 
However, as learned from the experience of the TA for Implementing Impact Evaluation at ADB, 
the TA may support key phases of individual studies; for example, to be approved by the Impact 
Evaluation  Committee (IEC),  only  the  design and  conduct  of the  baseline  survey  may  be 
implemented under the TA, while the mid-line and end-line surveys can be financed through 
separate initiatives.4 Through this component, the TA will provide direct technical support by 
individual and firm consultants and ERD specialists to individual studies by advising on design, 
methodology, and application in all phases of the study.  
 
12.  Component 2: Development of impact evaluation methodologies, approaches, and 
capacities. The second component will entail a number of activities, including (i) reviewing 
impact evaluation methodologies and improvements in techniques and tools for sector- and 
theme-specific studies; (ii) conducting pilot studies to test sector- or theme-specific techniques 
and tools; (iii) conducting impact evaluation awareness raising and capacity building for DMC 
officials and ADB staff; (iv) establishing and maintaining a central impact evaluation data portal 
containing information on project baseline, mid-line, and end-line surveys (e.g., questionnaires, 
sampling methodology, interviewer manuals, field data); and (v) conducting knowledge-sharing 
                                                
3  Impact evaluation is mainstreamed in ADB operations when it is integrated in the process of designing projects in 
DMCs based on gained experiences from actual conduct of impact evaluation studies adopting appropriate 
methodology, knowledge-sharing workshops and conferences, and capacity building activities.  
4  If only the study design or baseline survey can be implemented under the TA, the IEC may require commitment 
from regional departments concerned to have mid-line and/or end-line surveys and/or studies undertaken in the 
future.

4   
activities  (i.e.,  regional  conferences  where  impact  evaluation  studies  conducted  will  be 
presented;  and  workshops  and  seminars  where  experts  will  be  invited  to  share  methods, 
practices,  and  lessons  on  impact  evaluation)  and  publishing  and  disseminating  impact 
evaluation studies (publishing impact evaluation studies for distribution to ADB and government 
counterparts, and uploading studies to the ADB website). 
 
3.  Subsequent Subprojects (Subprojects 2 and 3) 
 
13.  The subsequent subprojects will also be structured along the lines of the components 
described in subproject 1. Subprojects 2-3 will also have two components: (i) impact evaluation 
studies, and (ii) development of impact evaluation methodologies, approaches, and capacities. 
The design of subprojects 2-3 is envisaged benefitting from the lessons from implementing 
subproject 1. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $4,500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). Each subproject is estimated to cost 
$1,500,000. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB  will  be  the  overall  executing  agency for the TA,  which  will  commence  on  31 
January 2013 and will be completed on 31 March 2017. An IEC will be established, comprising 
representatives (one principal and the alternate)5 from ADB’s regional departments, ERD, the 
Regional and Sustainable Development Department, and Central Operations Services Office, 
and will be chaired by one of the regional department representatives. The IEC will provide 
overall  guidance  and  oversight  for  the  TA,  including  allocation  of  resources  under  each 
component. The IED will be invited as an observer. For component 1, the regional departments 
will propose and, if approved by the IEC, implement impact evaluation studies.6  The IEC 
approval will require commitment from regional departments to have mid-line and/or end-line 
surveys/studies  undertaken  in  case  only  the  study  design  or  baseline  survey  can  be 
implemented under the proposed C-RDTA. The regional departments will be responsible for the 
final outputs of the impact evaluation studies, including reports, and for the quality of their 
respective studies. ERD will provide support to regional departments on the technical design 
and implementation of impact evaluation studies, and in the preparation and finalization of 
impact evaluation studies and reports. Results of impact evaluation studies will be published as 
part of project completion reports or as stand-alone working papers. The collection of data sets 
will be supervised by the impact evaluation study team members and staff assigned by the IEC 
to ensure their quality. ERD will propose, and if approved by the IEC, implement activities that 
fall under component 2 of the TA in collaboration with regional departments.7 
 
16.  Each  of  the  impact  evaluation  studies  will  require  a  team  of  consultants,  both 
international and national, to be engaged separately. The consultants will (i) provide technical 
guidance  and  feedback  on  the  evaluation  studies,  (ii)  develop  the  design  of  the  impact 
evaluation  studies  together  with  the  ADB  team,  (iii)  assist  in  guiding  and  overseeing  the 
                                                
5  Alternate representatives will also be nominated to represent principal representatives in case the principal 
representatives are not available for a meeting. 
6  No-objection will be sought from the respective governments of DMCs to be covered under this TA prior to 
commencing the impact evaluation studies. 
7  Proposals from regional departments, the Regional and Sustainable Development Department, and the Central 
Operations Services Office are also welcome under component 2. If approved by the IEC, the activities shall be 
jointly implemented by the initiator and ERD.

5 
implementation of impact evaluation studies, (iv) assist in survey designs, (v) implement the 
surveys, and (vi) assist in data analysis and report evaluation. Cost estimates for consulting 
services will be prepared in consultation with the divisions implementing the individual impact 
evaluation studies. Consultant packages for each impact evaluation study will comprise both 
firms and individuals, as appropriate. About 21 person-months of international and 45 person-
months  of  national  consulting  services  will  be  required  to  implement  the  TA  components. 
Consultants  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for 
consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
17.  Procurement  of  equipment  (computer  hardware  and  software)  by  ADB  will  be  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
Procurement will take place in coordination with ADB’s Office of Information Systems and 
Technology and Office of Administrative Services. When the TA is completed, any procured 
equipment will remain ADB property and/or will be disposed of in accordance with relevant ADB 
guidelines. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
18.  The TA will involve partnership with recognized impact evaluation research institutes and 
global  centers  of  excellence,  such  as  the  International  Initiative  for  Impact  Evaluation, 
Innovations for Poverty Action, or the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab. Such partnerships 
will largely be in terms of exchange of knowledge and participation of resource persons in 
training and consultation workshops. The TA will shoulder the incremental cost for resource 
persons if necessary. 
 
19.  ERD  will  report  on  the  progress  of  the  TA  and  the  individual  studies  through  the 
established  project  performance  management  systems  in  coordination  with  the  regional 
departments and other concerned departments. A number of reports on the individual studies 
will  also  be  produced  under  the  TA,  and  these  will  be  disseminated  through  seminars, 
workshops, or conferences. A consolidated TA completion report will be prepared for the TA. No 
separate TA completion reports need to be prepared for the subprojects. For preparation of the 
consolidated  completion  report,  each  impact  evaluation  study  team  will  provide  complete 
information to the TA project officer. Further details on implementation arrangements are in the 
supplementary appendix (available on request). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
 
20.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $4,500,000 on a grant basis for Developing Impact Evaluation 
Methodologies, Approaches, and Capacities in Selected Developing Member Countries.

10     Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Impact  evaluation  advisor  (4  person-months,  intermittent).  The  impact  evaluation 
advisor should have more than 15 years of experience and a well-established reputation in 
impact evaluation research and practice. The advisor will mainly provide technical guidance and 
feedback on the evaluation studies under this technical assistance (TA). Specifically, the advisor 
will 
(i)  review and provide detailed comments and suggestions on the inception reports 
prepared by the impact evaluation specialists, 
(ii)  review and provide detailed comments and suggestions on the draft final impact 
evaluation studies, 
(iii)  provide  guidance  on  questions  raised  by  the  evaluation  team  regarding  the 
evaluation studies, 
(iv)  participate in the dissemination activities as requested, and 
(v)  provide guidance on the contents of the study website. 
 
2.  International  impact  evaluation  specialists  (12  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
international impact evaluation specialists should have sufficient expertise and experience in 
impact evaluation of public interventions and a good understanding of the project sector in 
developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). They will design 
the evaluation, guide and oversee its implementation, and produce high-quality deliverables. 
Specifically, the specialists will 
(i)  conduct a desk review of project documents and coordinate with the project team 
in designing and implementing the evaluation; 
(ii)  conduct a literature review with assistance from the national impact evaluation 
specialists; 
(iii)  identify  and  access  existing  data  sources  with  assistance  from  the  national 
specialists; 
(iv)  design an evaluation framework and develop an action plan for implementation; 
(v)  prepare an inception report that includes a description of the intervention to be 
evaluated,  evaluation  questions,  evaluation  design,  implementation  plan,  and 
other information requested by the project team; 
(vi)  design survey instruments and guide the national specialists and survey team in 
the conduct of surveys; 
(vii)  conduct empirical analysis of the impacts of the project; 
(viii)  prepare a final report with details of the impact evaluation study, highlighting 
lessons learned and recommendations for future operations; and 
(ix)  assist in disseminating the evaluation findings through academic publications, 
policy briefs, and/or seminars and workshops. 
 
3.  Copy editor (2.5 person-months). The copy editor will ensure that the outputs under this 
TA adhere to ADB style and usage, and conform to high publication standards. The consultant 
should have expertise in copy editing and desktop publishing, and preferably have extensive 
experience in similar assignments involving preparation of economic publications. 
 
4.  Impact evaluation trainers (2.5 person-months, intermittent). The impact evaluation 
trainers should be familiar with the impact evaluation literature and key development issues in 
ADB’s DMCs. They should also have practical experience in impact evaluation in developing 
countries. The trainers will

Appendix 3  11  
(i)  design training courses for ADB’s DMC officials covering common experimental 
and non-experimental methods of impact evaluation, their respective merits and 
drawbacks, and circumstances where they are applicable; 
(ii)  prepare training materials, including case studies to illustrate possible scenarios 
that the participants may face; and 
(iii)  prepare reports on course effectiveness based on feedback from participants and 
other indicators. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
5.  National impact evaluation specialists (20 person-months, intermittent). The national 
impact evaluation specialists should have sufficient expertise and experience in survey design 
and  implementation  and  good  knowledge  of  the  project  sector  and  of  impact  evaluation 
methodologies and application. Guided by the international impact evaluation specialists, they 
will assist in survey design, implement the surveys, and assist in data analysis and report 
preparation. Specifically, the specialists will 
(i)  assist  the  international  specialists  in  literature  review  and  in  identifying  and 
accessing existing data sources; 
(ii)  assist the international specialists in developing the impact evaluation framework 
and action plan; 
(iii)  conduct pretests of survey instruments and assist the international specialists in 
improving the survey design; 
(iv)  guide the survey team and implement surveys for data collection; 
(v)  coordinate  between the  international specialists,  project team,  and  executing 
agencies; 
(vi)  assist the international specialists in data analysis and report preparation; and 
(vii)  participate in and contribute to the dissemination activities. 
 
6.  Project  coordinator (5 person-months, intermittent). The project coordinator should 
have sufficient experience in coordinating research projects. Specifically, the project coordinator 
will 
(i)  follow up and update the TA project team and the Impact Evaluation Committee 
with progress of the evaluation study; 
(ii)  prepare periodic reports on project progress, and/or as requested; 
(iii)  monitor budget utilization by regional departments; 
(iv)  design, maintain, and update the study websites; 
(v)  consolidate TA reports as needed; and 
(vi)  coordinate events related to the project. 
 
7.  Research assistants (as needed). The research assistants should be familiar with the 
impact evaluation literature and have experience in data processing and analysis. Under the 
guidance of the impact evaluation specialists, the research assistants will 
(i)  collect, clean, and analyze data; 
(ii)  assist in preparing presentations, reports, and other publications; and 
(iii)  provide inputs to the study website.
author_page:
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ERD  –  Economics and Research Department 
  IEC  –  Impact Evaluation Committee 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Cluster—Research and development technical assistance  
(C-RDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Public  sector  management  (economic  and  public  affairs 
management) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting economic efficiency and enabling 
business  environment,  widening  access  to  markets  and 
economic  opportunities);  social  development  (human 
development);  private  sector  development  (policy  reforms); 
capacity development (institutional development) 
Location (impact)  –  Rural (high); urban (high) 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  B. N. Lohani, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development 
Chief Economist  C. Rhee, Economics and Research Department (ERD) 
Assistant Chief  C.Y. Park, Economic Analysis and Operations Support Division, ERD 
Economist 
   
Team leader  K. Y. Nam, Senior Economist, ERD 
Team members  R. Bolt, Advisor, Southeast Asia Department 
J. Brommelhorster, Principal Economist, East Asia Department 
H. Carlsson, Lead Development Effectiveness Specialist, South Asia 
Department 
C. Edmonds, Senior Economist, Pacific Department 
P. R. Halili, Economics Officer, ERD 
T. Tamaki, Principal Regional Economist, Central and West Asia 
Department 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.
